keyTakeAways: A steel cable on the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed to meet operational specifications and was not certified to carry passengers.
The cable snapped shortly after the funicular cars began their journey on Calçada da Glória, causing one car to derail and crash into a building.
Eyewitnesses described the incident as chaotic and uncontrolled, with one man named Bruno recounting hearing screams and seeing a cloud of brown smoke.
The preliminary report from GPIAAF identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
Maintenance tasks were falsely marked as completed, and the maintenance plan was recorded as compliant despite non-compliance.
The operator, CARRIS, failed to ensure the cable met its own specifications, indicating a systemic oversight in safety protocols.
The preliminary findings are not conclusive, and a final report is expected next year.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A preliminary investigation by the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) found that a steel cable on the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed to meet safety specifications and was not certified for passenger use, leading to a deadly crash in September 2025. The cable snapped shortly after the funicular cars began their journey on Calçada da Glória, resulting in at least 16 deaths and multiple injuries. Eyewitnesses, including a man named Bruno, described the event as sudden and catastrophic, with one car derailing and crashing into a building. The investigation revealed serious deficiencies in maintenance practices, including falsified completion records and a maintenance plan marked as compliant despite non-compliance. While the findings are preliminary, they highlight systemic failures in safety oversight by the operator, CARRIS, and underscore the need for stricter compliance with technical and operational standards.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
